conclusion: Two cars, A and B, are moving in the same direction on a straight road with B in front. They start braking simultaneously after hearing a siren.

The graph shows Car A starting at 25 m/s and Car B at 15 m/s, both decelerating linearly. Car A reaches zero velocity at 30 seconds, Car B at 25 seconds. Their velocity lines intersect at 20 seconds with a velocity of around 5 m/s.
The slope of the velocity-time graph gives acceleration, and the area under the graph represents distance traveled.
Since they collide, Car A catches up to Car B, meaning x_A = x_B at collision.
The key is to find when the collision occurs relative to the 20-second mark.
Calculate slope for Car A: (0 - 25)/(30 - 0) = -5/6 m/s², so v_A = 25 - (5/6)t.
Calculate slope for Car B: (0 - 15)/(25 - 0) = -3/5 m/s², so v_B = 15 - (3/5)t.
Velocity intersection at t=20 s gives v=25 - (5/6)*20 ≈ 8.33 m/s, but image shows around 5 m/s.
Integrate velocity equations to find position: x_A = 25t - (5/12)t², x_B = 15t - (3/10)t².
Set x_A = x_B to find collision: 25t - (5/12)t² = 15t - (3/10)t².
Solve for t: 10t + t²(-7)/60 = 0, giving t=0 or t≈85.71 s.
Realize t≈85.71 s is beyond braking times, indicating collision occurs before both stop.
